choices.text: Ketamine
Thiopental
Etomidate
Propofol

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy as a day care surgery. She is otherwise healthy with no significant medical history. Which of the following intravenous anesthetic agents would be the ideal choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Propofol

 

 

Option D. Propofol is the ideal choice for this scenario. It has a rapid onset of action and a short half-life, which leads to quick recovery times, making it perfect for day care surgeries. It also has antiemetic properties which reduce the incidence of PONV, an important consideration for day care procedures.

Duration of action of Propofol is 2-8 min.

 

 

Explanation:

Option A. Ketamine - While ketamine is a potent anesthetic and analgesic agent, it can lead to a significant increase in heart rate and blood pressure, and potentially hallucinations upon emergence. It's not typically the first choice for day care surgeries.

 

Option B. Thiopental - Thiopental is a barbiturate that can provide rapid induction, but it has a longer duration of action and recovery time compared to other agents. It is also associated with a high incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), which is not ideal for day care surgery.

 

Option C. Etomidate - Etomidate provides rapid induction and has a short duration of action. However, it lacks analgesic properties and can cause adrenal suppression, making it less desirable for this scenario.

 

Educational objective –

 

  • Day care anesthesia, also known as ambulatory anesthesia or outpatient anesthesia, refers to the administration of anesthesia for surgical or medical procedures that are performed on an outpatient basis, typically in a healthcare facility such as a hospital, surgical center, or clinic. In day care anesthesia, patients undergo anesthesia for their procedure and are discharged on the same day once they have recovered from the effects of anesthesia and the procedure itself.
  • This approach allows patients to return home or to a non-hospital setting shortly after their surgery or intervention, without the need for an overnight hospital stay.
  • Day care anesthesia is commonly used for a wide range of elective and minimally invasive procedures, and it aims to provide effective anesthesia while minimizing the patient's length of stay in the healthcare facility.

Reference : Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 5th edition pg 171,186,920

choices.text: Renal Failure due to Sepsis
Respiratory Failure due to Over Sedation

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented to emergency with cough, fever, and abdominal and back pain for one week. She had tachycardia, tachypnoea, hypotension and bilateral rales on auscultation. Chest radiographs revealed rounded densities in the right middle lung. Initial assessment of the chest radiographs signified acute respiratory failure with severe sepsis, likely secondary to pneumonia. The patient was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, started on vasopressors, antibiotics, propofol and midazolam for sedation. Her condition worsened and that resulted in increased doses of all sedative agents and the addition of fentanyl. 2-3 days later, she developed generalized rash over the body along with elevated Creatinine, sinus tachycardia, diastolic dysfunction and metabolic acidosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Propofol Infusion Syndrome

 

Option D. The described clinical features, including metabolic acidosis, multiple organ failure, hemodynamic instability, hepatomegaly, and rash, are indicative of propofol infusion syndrome. This syndrome is associated with prolonged high dose propofol infusions and can lead to severe complications, including organ dysfunction and metabolic derangements.

1st sign of Propofol infusion syndrome is Abnormal levels of Lipemia

 

Explanation:

Option A. Renal Failure due to Sepsis: While sepsis can lead to Acute Kidney Injury (AKI), the clinical presentation described in the scenario, including a generalized rash, sinus tachycardia, diastolic dysfunction, and metabolic acidosis, is not primarily indicative of renal failure.

 

Option B. Fentanyl Overdose: While fentanyl is an opioid that can lead to respiratory depression when overdosed, the symptoms mentioned in the scenario, such as a generalized rash and diastolic dysfunction, are not typical of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Respiratory Failure due to Over Sedation: Over-sedation with propofol, midazolam, and fentanyl can cause respiratory depression, but the additional symptoms like rash, diastolic dysfunction, and metabolic acidosis are not consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

Essential features of propofol infusion syndrome are metabolic acidosis, multiple organ failure, hemodynamic instability, hepatomegaly, and rhabdomyolysis. It occurs due to long term propofol infusion (> 48 hours) for sedation at high doses (>5 mg/kg/hr) leading to impaired fatty acid metabolism in the body.

 

Patients will have Green color Urine as Propofol contains Phenol.

1st sign of Propofol infusion syndrome is Abnormal levels of Lipemia

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s anaesthesiology 7th edition page 338

questions.text: During an Anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ischemia

 

Explanation:-

 

Option A. Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to severe complications, the most likely of which in this patient is ischemia. This occurs because the injection of the drug directly into an artery can cause thrombosis, vasospasm, and a lack of blood flow to the affected limb, resulting in ischemia. The initial symptom is typically burning pain, and the affected limb may become pale due to vasospasm. This complication is commonly seen when thiopentone is injected in antecubital vein because in 10% of the case brachial artery divides above elbow giving a very superficial abnormal ulnar artery which lies deep to antecubital vein. Therefore, thiopentone injection should be avoided at antecubital fossa and it should be given in the veins over the outer aspect of forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to complications such as ischemia, which can result in severe pain and pallor in the affected limb due to thrombosis and vasospasm. It is essential to avoid injecting Thiopentone into arteries to prevent this complication.

 

The management of intra-arterial injection of thiopentone includes –

 

  • Leaving Needle in situ in the Artery
  • Brachial Plexus Block (Stellate Ganglion Block)
  • Heparin Injection → To prevent Thrombosis.
  • Dilution of Thiopental by injection of Saline into the Artery
  • Papaverine or Prostacyclin injection – to relieve Spasm.
  • Urokinase, Streptokinase, Vasodilators, Steroid and Lignocaine can also be used in uncompensated Myocardial Disease.

 

 

REF: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition • Page no. 832

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding Laryngeal mask airway?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) More Tooth and Laryngeal Trauma

 

Option D. One of the advantages of the LMA is that it typically causes less tooth and laryngeal trauma compared to endotracheal tubes, which require direct laryngoscopy and can cause more mechanical trauma during insertion.

 

Explanation:

 

The Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device placed with its tip in the hypopharynx.

 

Option A. Less Invasive: This is true. The LMA is considered less invasive than endotracheal intubation because it does not enter the trachea and is placed in the hypopharynx.

 

Option B. Better Hemodynamic Stability: This is often true as well. Insertion of an LMA is usually associated with less hemodynamic stimulation compared to endotracheal intubation.

 

Option C. Very Useful in Difficult Intubations: This is true, especially for certain types of LMAs designed for difficult airways, like the Fastrach LMA.

 

The answer provided, Option D, is correct. The LMA is known for causing less, not more, tooth and laryngeal trauma compared to endotracheal intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Laryngeal Mask Airway is known for being less invasive with a reduced risk of causing tooth and laryngeal trauma, offering better hemodynamic stability during insertion, and serving as a useful tool in managing difficult airways.

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition page 1662

choices.text: Operating Room Cart

questions.text: Identify the instruments given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crash Cart

 

Option A. A crash cart contains emergency medical supplies and medication that are used in cardiac arrest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Airway Cart: An airway cart is equipped with various sizes of laryngoscope blades, endotracheal tubes, masks, laryngeal mask airways, and possibly also advanced equipment like flexible fiberoptic intubation tools. The cart in the image is consistent with the equipment one would expect in an airway cart.

 

Option C. Operating Room Cart: While an operating room cart may contain a variety of surgical instruments and supplies, the specific collection of airway equipment seen here is more specialized than what would be found in a general operating room cart.

 

Option D. Intubation Cart: An intubation cart would contain equipment specifically for intubation, and while this could be another name for an airway cart, the term "airway cart" is more inclusive, covering a broader range of airway management tools, not just those for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Components of a Crash Cart:

 

  • Medications

 

Medications are usually kept in the top drawer of most crash carts

 

  • Intubation

 

Many crash carts will also include most of the materials necessary to perform intubation.These may be contained in the third or fourth drawers depending on the setup of the particular crash cart.

 

  • Intravenous lines

 

It is usually the case that the equipment necessary to start an IV is in a separate drawer from materials needed to maintain an IV, such as the fluids in the tubing.

 

  • Procedure drawer

 

The bottom drawer on crash carts is usually devoted to keeping prepackaged kits available for various urgent and emergent procedures (or it is where the IV solutions are kept).

 

 

Ref: https://www.aclsmedicaltraining.com/crash-carts/

choices.text: Mobility of cervical spine
Mobility of atlanto-axial joint
Assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation
Inspection of oral cavity before intubation

questions.text: Mallampatti’s classification is to check for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inspection of oral cavity before intubation 

 

 

Option D. Inspection of the oral cavity before intubation: This is the correct purpose of Mallampati's classification. It involves visualizing the patient's mouth, tongue, tonsils, and the ability to see the posterior pharyngeal structures to determine the ease or difficulty of intubation. Mallampati's classification is divided into several classes (from I to IV), with Class I indicating a clear view of all structures and Class IV indicating no visibility beyond the hard palate.

 

 

Explanation:-

Option A. Mobility of cervical spine: This option is unrelated to Mallampati's classification. Cervical spine mobility refers to the range of motion of the neck and is assessed for different purposes.

 

Option B. Mobility of atlanto-axial joint: Similar to option A, the mobility of the atlanto-axial joint is not assessed using Mallampati's classification. The atlanto-axial joint is the joint between the first and second cervical vertebrae and is evaluated for specific clinical conditions.

 

Option C. Assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation: While the ability to freely rotate the neck can be important for intubation, it is not the primary purpose of Mallampati's classification. Instead, Mallampati's classification focuses on the visibility and accessibility of the oral and pharyngeal structures.

 

Educational Objective:-
 

Mallampatti’s classification

Mallampati's classification is a method used by anesthetists to assess the anatomical structures of a patient's oral cavity and throat before intubation, which is the process of inserting a breathing tube into the patient's airway. The classification helps predict the ease or difficulty of intubation and can aid in planning for the safest and most appropriate airway management technique.

  • Mallampatti’s score helps in oral cavity assessment to rule out difficult intubation (Inspection of oral cavity before intubation)
  • It also helps in sleep apnea evaluation.
  • Mallampatti’s score is divided into four grades
     

 

 

Ref:-: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesia 6th edition page 611

choices.text: Morphine
Bupivacaine
Midazolam
Fentanyl

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly used as the drug of choice for spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bupivacaine

 

 

Option B. Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic that's often used for spinal anesthesia. It provides both sensory and motor blockage, making it suitable for a wide range of surgical procedures. Bupivacaine is known for its longer duration of action compared to other local anesthetics, making it a common choice for procedures requiring a longer period of anesthesia.

 

Explanation :

Option A. Morphine - This is an opioid medication that can be used as part of a spinal anesthesia regimen for its pain-relieving properties. However, it's typically used as an adjunct, not as the primary anesthetic agent.

 

Option C. Midazolam - Midazolam is a benzodiazepine, which is typically used for its sedative properties and is not typically used as the primary agent for spinal anesthesia.

 

Option D. Fentanyl - Like morphine, fentanyl is an opioid that can be used as part of a spinal anesthesia regimen for its analgesic properties. It is also used as an adjunct and not as the primary anesthetic agent for spinal anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:-

Bupivacaine is the drug of choice for spinal anesthesia due to its ability to provide prolonged sensory and motor blockade suitable for various surgical procedures."

 

Reference : Miller’s anesthesia 8th edition page 1043-1044

questions.text: Which of these factors does not affect Minimum Alveolar Concentration of inhalational anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gender

 

Option D. Gender does not significantly affect the MAC of inhalational anesthetics, which is why it is the correct answer to the question.

 

Explanation:

 

The Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) of inhalational anesthetic agents is the concentration needed to prevent movement in 50% of patients in response to a surgical stimulus. Several factors can influence MAC, but gender is not one of them.

 

Option A. Age: MAC is affected by age, with younger patients generally requiring higher concentrations of anesthetic agents and older patients requiring less.

 

Option B. Pregnancy: Pregnancy can lower the MAC due to various physiological changes, including hormonal variations and increased levels of endogenous opioids.

 

Option C. Temperature: The body's temperature can influence MAC; hypothermia tends to decrease MAC, while hyperthermia can increase it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When considering the appropriate concentration of an inhalational anesthetic, factors like age, pregnancy, and body temperature must be taken into account as they can affect the MAC value. However, gender does not significantly influence the MAC of these agents.
 

Factors affecting minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

 

Note - Gender & thyroid disorder does not affect Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

 

Ref:- Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 7th edition pg 281-284

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a routine monitor used in all types of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Invasive Blood Pressure Monitoring

 

 

Option D. This type of monitoring involves inserting a catheter into an artery (typically in the wrist) to measure blood pressure continuously. While invasive blood pressure monitoring provides very accurate readings, it is not routine in all types of anesthesia. It's typically reserved for high-risk or complex surgeries where rapid changes in blood pressure are anticipated, or in cases where it is particularly important to have continuous, precise blood pressure measurements. For many types of anesthesia, non-invasive blood pressure monitoring is sufficient.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulse oximetry is a standard monitor used in all types of anesthesia. It measures the oxygen saturation of the patient's blood, which is crucial in maintaining patient safety.

 

 

 

Option B. Capnography measures the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, providing information about the patient's respiratory status. It's a standard part of monitoring under anesthesia.

 

 

Option C. Electrocardiography is also standard in any type of anesthesia. It allows the anesthesiologist to monitor the heart's electrical activity, helping detect any cardiac irregularities.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Invasive Blood Pressure Monitoring is not routinely used in all types of anesthesia; it is typically reserved for high-risk patients or complex surgeries where close monitoring of blood pressure is necessary. Pulse Oximetry, Capnography, and Electrocardiography (ECG) are standard non-invasive monitors used across various anesthesia settings.

Reference : Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 1349-1350

questions.text: Identify the inhaled anaesthetic agent which is an NMDA receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Xenon

 

Option B. This is a rare gas that provides anesthesia primarily through the inhibition of the NMDA receptor, which is a subtype of glutamate receptor in the nervous system. It’s known for its minimal side effects and lack of environmental impact.

 

Explanation:

 

Inhaled Anaesthetic Agent which is an NMDA Receptor Antagonist- Xenon.

 

Intravenous Anaesthetic Agent which is an NMDA Receptor Antagonist- Ketamine

 

Option A. Nitrous Oxide: It is an inhalational anesthetic with analgesic properties. It works partially through the inhibition of NMDA receptors, but it is not as potent an NMDA antagonist as xenon.

 

Option C. Sevoflurane: A commonly used volatile anesthetic agent, it is preferred for its rapid onset and offset due to its low blood/gas solubility coefficient. Sevoflurane acts on multiple targets, including GABA receptors, but not predominantly on NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Desflurane: Also, a Volatile Anesthetic, desflurane has a rapid onset and emergence, much like sevoflurane. It is known for its pungent odor and irritancy, making it less ideal for inhalation induction. It does not act primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When considering NMDA receptor antagonists among inhalational anesthetic agents, xenon is unique for its potent antagonistic effect on NMDA receptors, offering an environmentally friendly profile and minimal side effects, distinct from nitrous oxide, sevoflurane, and desflurane which have different primary mechanisms of action.

 

 

Ref:- Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice latest edition 5th edition pg 102,103.

questions.text: In which of these patients is Rapid Sequence Intubation not indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anxious Patients

 

Option C. Anxiety alone is not an indication for RSI. While anxious patients may require a different approach to induction and securing the airway, the presence of anxiety does not increase the risk of aspiration.

 

Explanation:

 

Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) is a technique used to secure the airway rapidly in situations where there is a High risk of Aspiration.

 

Option A. Pregnancy: RSI is indicated in pregnancy, particularly during the second and third trimesters, due to the increased risk of aspiration caused by delayed gastric emptying and the upward pressure of the gravid uterus on the stomach.

 

Option B. Presence of Nasogastric Tube: Although the presence of a nasogastric tube might suggest recent feeding or an obstructed stomach, RSI is still indicated because of the potential risk of regurgitation and aspiration.

 

Option D. Diabetic Gastroparesis: Diabetic patients with gastroparesis have delayed gastric emptying, which puts them at a higher risk for aspiration. RSI is indicated in these patients to minimize this risk during the induction of anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid Sequence Intubation is indicated in situations where there is an increased risk of aspiration, such as in patients with a full stomach, pregnancy, presence of a nasogastric tube, morbid obesity, and conditions like diabetic gastroparesis. It is not indicated solely based on patient anxiety.

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 1382.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of Rapid sequence induction in the correct order?

 

  1. Pre-oxygenation with 100% 02
  2. IV Succinylcholine
  3. Administration of rapidly acting IV induction agent
  4. Sellick's manoeuvre (cricoid pressure) by assistant
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Steps of Rapid Sequence Induction:

 

  1. Pre-oxygenation with 100% 02
  2. Sellick's manoeuvre (cricoid pressure) by assistant
  3. Administration of rapidly acting IV induction agent
  4. IV Succinylcholine
  5. Do NOT ventilate patient
  6. Direct laryngoscopy and intubation
  7. Confirm endotracheal tube placement
  8. Remove cricoid pressure
     

 

Educational Objective 

 

The accurate sequence of RSI is pre-oxygenation with 100% O2, application of Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), administration of a rapidly acting IV induction agent, followed by IV succinylcholine.

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition Page no. 1382

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a minor ambulatory surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anaesthesiologist plans to use an induction agent that allows for rapid emergence post-procedure. Which of the following agent is the preferred induction agent used in day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propofol

 

Option A. Propofol is a preferred induction agent in day care surgery. It offers a rapid onset of anesthesia and allows for quick emergence post-procedure. Its short duration of action and amnestic effects make it suitable for ambulatory surgical procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option B. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is not typically the first choice for induction in day care surgery. While it is an ultra short-acting barbiturate, it may have a slower recovery profile compared to propofol.

 

Option C. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anaesthetic agent that can provide rapid induction and analgesia. However, it may not be the preferred choice for day care surgery due to its potential for hallucinations and psychomimetic effects during emergence.

 

Option D. Diazepam: Diazepam is not commonly used as an induction agent in day care surgery. It is more often utilized for preoperative anxiolysis and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In day care surgery, the choice of induction agent is crucial for achieving rapid onset of anesthesia and ensuring quick emergence to facilitate patient recovery and discharge. Propofol is often preferred in such settings due to its favorable pharmacokinetic profile.

 

Preferable agents in Day Care AnesthesiaBottom of Form

  • Muscle Relaxant of Choice – Scoline or Rocuronium/Sugammadex combination
  • Sevoflurane (Volatile Inhalational Agent)
  • Opioid- Remifentanil
  • Propofol (inducing Agent of Choice)
  • Midazolam (for Initial Anxiolysis and Sedation)

 

 

REF: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition

questions.text: A 21-year-old posted for shoulder arthroscopy under general anaesthesia gives history of sudden rise in temperature under anaesthesia in previous surgery. You want to closely monitor the core body temperature of this patient. Which would be the best site to put the temperature probe in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pulmonary Artery

 

Option D. The pulmonary artery temperature is considered one of the most accurate methods for measuring core body temperature. A specialized catheter with a temperature probe, known as a pulmonary artery catheter or Swan-Ganz catheter, is inserted into the pulmonary artery. Given its proximity to the heart and large blood volume, it offers an accurate reflection of core body temperature.

 

Explanation:

 

While all these sites can be used to measure body temperature, the pulmonary artery provides the most accurate measurement of core body temperature, especially in high-risk situations or during major surgeries.

 

Option A. Axilla: The axilla (or armpit) is a common site for measuring body temperature, especially in outpatient settings or for less invasive surgeries. However, axillary temperature measurements can be influenced by the surrounding environment and may not provide the most accurate representation of core body temperature, especially during major surgeries or situations where precise core temperature measurement is required.

 

Option B. Tympanic membrane: The tympanic membrane (or eardrum) reflects the temperature of the brain's blood flow, making it a more accurate measure of core body temperature than the axilla. Infrared tympanic thermometers measure the infrared radiation emitted by the tympanic membrane. It's non-invasive and provides relatively quick readings. However, it can be influenced by factors like ear wax, ear infections, or incorrect placement of the probe.

 

Option C. Oesophagus: It provides a close approximation to core body temperature and is often used during major surgeries. This method is less influenced by external factors, making it more accurate than axillary or tympanic measurements. However, it's still not the most accurate site for core body temperature monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Site for Core Temperature Measurement

 

 

 

Ref:- Short textbook of anaesthesia Ajay Yadav page 66

questions.text: In which of the below conditions will Ketamine be most preferred in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyper-Reactive Airways

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. Ketamine is a potent bronchodilator and is often preferred in patients with hyper-reactive airways, such as those with asthma, because it can relieve bronchospasm and maintain airway function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ischemic Heart Disease: Ketamine is generally avoided in patients with ischemic heart disease because it can increase cardiac oxygen demand and blood pressure, which can be detrimental in such patients.

 

Option B. Intracranial Hemorrhage: Ketamine is contraindicated in patients with intracranial hemorrhage as it can increase intracranial pressure, potentially worsening the condition.

 

Option D. Glaucoma: Ketamine is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma as it can significantly increase intraocular pressure, which can be harmful to the eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is most preferred in patients with hyper-reactive airways (hyperresponsive or reactive airways, such as asthma) because it acts as a potent bronchodilator and can relieve bronchospasm.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 332

choices.text: Tumour in the Right Lung
Coronary Artery Bypass Graft

questions.text: Which of these is not an indication of the use of the endotracheal tube shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Coronary Artery Bypass Graft

 

The tube shown in the picture is a Double Lumen Tube used for one lung ventilation in Thoracic surgery.

 

Option D. For CABG, one-lung ventilation is not typically required. The surgery is performed on the heart, and standard endotracheal intubation is usually sufficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bronchopleural Fistula: This condition can benefit from a double-lumen tube, as it allows ventilation of one lung while the other lung or the fistula is isolated or treated.

 

Option B. Tumour in the Right Lung: A double-lumen tube would be indicated here to allow for the collapse of the affected lung to facilitate surgical access and treatment.

 

Option C. VATS Esophagectomy: During Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) for esophagectomy, a double-lumen tube allows for one-lung ventilation, which can provide a better surgical field by deflating the lung on the side of the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double-lumen endotracheal tube is used for procedures requiring one-lung ventilation, such as surgeries for bronchopleural fistula, lung tumors, and certain thoracoscopic procedures. It is not indicated for procedures like coronary artery bypass grafting, where one-lung ventilation is not necessary.

 

 

Ref: Principles and practice of anaesthesia for Thoracic surgery

choices.text: It causes rise in Intracranial Pressure.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with ischemic heart disease is sedated, ventilated in the ICU. You would not prefer Etomidate for continuous sedation in this patient because?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It results in Adrenal Suppression.

 

Option A. This statement is correct. Etomidate can lead to adrenal suppression by inhibiting 11 beta-hydroxylase, an enzyme involved in corticosteroid synthesis in the adrenal cortex. This inhibition can result in decreased synthesis of adrenal corticosteroids, which is a significant concern, especially in critically ill patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It may cause Vasospasm: This statement is not a typical side effect of Etomidate. Etomidate is not known for causing vasospasm as one of its primary effects. Instead, it is more commonly associated with adrenal suppression and potential cardiovascular effects.

 

Option C. It results in Cardiac Arrhythmias: Etomidate is generally considered to have a relatively stable cardiovascular profile and is less likely to cause cardiac arrhythmias compared to some other anesthetic agents. It is often used in patients with compromised cardiovascular function.

 

Option D. It causes a rise in Intracranial Pressure: Etomidate is actually known for causing a decrease in intracranial pressure, which can be advantageous in some situations, such as when managing patients with traumatic brain injury or increased intracranial pressure. It has a cerebral protective effect by reducing cerebral metabolic rate and intracranial pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etomidate is avoided for continuous sedation in critically ill patients due to its potential to cause adrenal suppression, which can increase the risk of mortality, especially in patients with ischemic heart disease or other critical conditions.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 7th edition page 334-336

choices.text: ASA-PS III
ASA-PS IV
ASA-PS V
ASA-PS VI

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with uncontrolled hypertension, hypertensive nephropathy, history of myocardial infarction posted for coronary artery bypass graft can be classified into?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ASA-PS IV

 

Explanation:-

In the case described, the patient is 70 years old with uncontrolled hypertension, hypertensive nephropathy, and a history of myocardial infarction. These comorbid conditions are severe and constant threats to the patient's life. Therefore, the patient falls into ASA-PS IV, as these medical conditions significantly increase the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.

 

 

Educational objective:-

ASA-PS IV classification is assigned to a patient with severe systemic disease and constant life-threatening risks, as seen in a 70-year-old with uncontrolled hypertension, hypertensive nephropathy, and a history of myocardial infarction undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

 

Ref:- Millers 8th edition page number 1144

choices.text: Ambulatory Manual Breathing Unit
Artificial Mechanical Breathing Unit
Artificial Manual Breathing Unit
Artificial Mechanical Breathing Unit

questions.text: What is the complete name of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Artificial Manual Breathing Unit

 

Explanation:

 

The device shown in the image is known as a Bag Valve Mask (BVM), which is a hand-held device commonly used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients who are not breathing or not breathing adequately. The device is also known colloquially as an “AMBU bag,” which stands for “Artificial Manual Breathing Unit.” Here is an explanation of each component labelled in the image:

 

  • Self-inflating Bag: This component allows the bag to reinflate after being squeezed, without requiring a gas supply. It fills with air or oxygen from an attached reservoir or oxygen supply.
  • Expiratory Valve: This allows the exhaled gas to escape the system so that it doesn’t re-enter the patient’s lungs.
  • PEEP Valve: Stands for Positive End-Expiratory Pressure valve, which maintains a small amount of pressure in the lungs to keep the alveoli open at the end of exhalation.
  • Face Mask: Fits over the patient’s nose and mouth to deliver breaths directly into the lungs.
  • Pop-off Valve: A safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessively high pressures which could damage the patient’s lungs.
  • Oxygen Inlet & Tubing: Connects the bag to an oxygen supply to deliver oxygen-enriched air to the patient.
  • Reservoir Bag: Allows a reservoir of oxygen to be available for the patient to ensure the highest possible concentration of oxygen is delivered.
  • Air-inlet One-way Valve & O2 Reservoir Socket: Prevents room air from entering the bag when attached to an oxygen supply and allows for the connection of an oxygen reservoir.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artificial Manual Breathing Unit (AMBU bag), is a critical device used in emergency medicine and anesthesia for providing ventilation to patients who are not breathing adequately on their own. The device features a self-inflating bag, face mask, oxygen reservoir, and various valves to ensure effective and safe delivery of oxygen to the patient.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 228

questions.text: Which of these arteries is best preferred for invasive blood pressure monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Radial artery

 

Explanation:

 

The Radial artery is the preferred site for invasive blood pressure monitoring for several reasons:

 

  1. Accessibility: The radial artery is superficial and is easily accessible. This makes cannulation of the radial artery relatively straightforward.
  2. Collateral Blood Flow: The hand has a dual blood supply, with both the ulnar and radial arteries contributing. This means that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand still has a blood supply from the ulnar artery. Before cannulation, the Allen's test can be done to ensure good ulnar artery perfusion.
  3. Stable Signal: The radial artery provides a stable and clear pressure waveform, which is essential for accurate monitoring.
  4. Low Complication Rate: Complications such as infection, thrombosis, or embolism are relatively lower in the radial artery compared to other sites.
  5. Patient Comfort: The wrist's position can be more comfortable for the patient compared to other potential sites for arterial line placement.
  6. Easy to Dress and Monitor: Because of its location, the site is easier for healthcare providers to dress, monitor, and manage, reducing the risk of complications.

 

 

Image showing Modified Allen Test – to check the patency of Ulnar Palmar Arch

 

Other arteries used for invasive blood pressure monitoring:

 

Dorsalis Pedis, Posterior Tibial, Superficial Temporal, Ulnar, Brachial, Femoral, and Axillary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radial artery is the preferred choice for invasive blood pressure monitoring for several reasons, including accessibility, collateral blood flow, stability of the pressure waveform, low complication rate, patient comfort, and ease of dressing and monitoring.

 

Advantages of Intra-arterial Blood Pressure monitoring:

1) Beat to Beat Monitoring which is essential for major surgeries like CABG, Transplant surgeries

2) For repeated ABG blood sampling

 

Ref:- Millers anesthesia 8th ed pg 1349-1350.

questions.text: A 16-year-old with posterior fossa meningioma is being operated in the sitting position. There is a sudden drop in etCO2 and sudden hypotension intra-operatively. Venous air embolism is suspected. What is the most sensitive monitor to detect the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Trans Esophageal Echo (TEE)

 

Option C. TEE provides real-time imaging of the heart's chambers and valves. When venous air embolism is suspected, TEE can directly visualize air bubbles in the heart, especially in the right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary artery. It is not only sensitive but also allows for quantification of the volume of air and can guide therapeutic interventions if needed. For these reasons, TEE is considered the most sensitive monitor for detecting venous air embolism, especially in the scenario described.

 

Explanation:

 

While several methods can detect venous air embolism, Transesophageal echo (TEE) is considered the most sensitive and provides the most detailed information, making it the best choice in the given scenario.
Let's discuss each option:

 

Option A. Precordial Doppler: This is a non-invasive ultrasound technique that's used to detect venous air embolism. The Doppler probe is placed over the cardiac area (precordium) and can detect the movement of air bubbles in the bloodstream. It's relatively sensitive and can detect small volumes of air. However, it can't quantify the amount of air or localize its position.

 

Option B. Mill Wheel Murmur: This is a specific type of heart murmur associated with venous air embolism. It is caused by air bubbles passing through the right side of the heart and is characterized by a churning or "mill-wheel" sound. It is an audible sign detected using a stethoscope but is not the most sensitive method to detect venous air embolism.

 

Option D. End Tidal Nitrogen Levels: When room air (which contains a significant amount of nitrogen) enters the bloodstream, the nitrogen content of the exhaled air (end-tidal gas) can increase. Monitoring the end-tidal nitrogen levels can thus be an indirect way of detecting venous air embolism. However, this method is less commonly used in clinical settings because it's not as sensitive as other methods, and it requires specialized equipment

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sitting position during neurosurgery, the mechanism of venous air embolism (VAE) primarily involves the potential entry of air through venous channels due to the patient's elevated head position. This elevation creates a gradient that allows air to be drawn into veins, leading to the formation of air emboli that can travel to the brain and cause neurological complications.

 

 

Ref:- Millers anaesthesia 9th ed pg 1879

choices.text: Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia
Patients with Chest Trauma
All of the Above

questions.text: In which of the following situations will you avoid the below procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

 

Optional A. In this condition, abdominal contents may herniate into the thoracic cavity, compromising lung function. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate this by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and further displacing abdominal contents into the chest, worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, it is typically avoided.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option B. Obese Patients: While BVM ventilation can be more challenging in obese patients due to anatomical considerations, it is not contraindicated. Appropriate modifications, like the ramp position, can be made to facilitate ventilation.

 

Option C. Patients with Chest Trauma: BVM ventilation is not necessarily contraindicated in chest trauma. It can be essential for providing life-saving ventilation, although care must be taken to avoid exacerbating certain injuries such as a tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. All of the Above: All of the above is not the correct choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BVM ventilation should be avoided in patients with congenital diaphragmatic hernia due to the risk of worsening respiratory distress by increasing intra-abdominal pressure, which can lead to furtherdisplacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in:

 

  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Rapid sequence induction

 

This is because it can increase intragastric pressure and cause aspiration.

 

 

Ref: Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 1659

Flexion of Neck, Extension of Head

questions.text: Ideal position for Intubation is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flexion of Neck, Extension of Head

 

Option B. Known as the 'Sniffing Position', this involves flexion at the lower cervical spine and extension at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, which is ideal for intubation.

The ideal position for intubation is to align the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes and is called The Sniffing Position.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexion of Head, Extension of Neck: This position would not align the axes appropriately for intubation.

 

Option C. Flexion of Head, Flexion of Neck: Both flexions would make it more difficult to align the axes and visualize the vocal cords.

 

Option D. Extension of Head, Extension of Neck: This would misalign the axes, making intubation more difficult.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'Sniffing Position', which involves flexion of the neck and extension of the head (modified Chevalier Jackson position), is the ideal position for endotracheal intubation. This position aligns the pharyngeal and laryngeal axes to facilitate direct laryngoscopy and intubation.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition pg 1393

questions.solution:

Option D: The ideal period for a chronic smoker to have stopped smoking before surgery is 6-8 weeks. This longer duration allows for the respiratory system to recover to a greater extent, reducing the risk of complications. It provides the best chances for improved lung function and overall surgical outcomes

 

Explanation:-

 

 

Educational Objective:-

 

The ideal period for a chronic smoker to have stopped smoking before surgery is 6-8 weeks. This duration allows for significant recovery of lung function and decreases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications.

questions.text: Identify the inhalational anaesthetic agent of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Desflurane

 

Option C: It has the lowest blood-gas solubility among the agents listed, allowing for rapid adjustment of depth of anesthesia and potentially quicker recovery, which is beneficial in morbidly obese patients due to reduced anesthesia time.

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a morbidly obese patient as shown in the image, the selection of an inhalational anesthetic agent should consider the solubility of the agent and its effects on recovery time post-surgery.

 

Option A: Sevoflurane – It's commonly used due to its minimal respiratory and cardiovascular effects. However, it has a higher blood-gas solubility than desflurane, potentially leading to a longer recovery time.

 

Option B: Isoflurane – Offers stable hemodynamics and is less expensive but has a higher blood-gas solubility, which may not be ideal for rapid emergence.

 

Option D: Methoxyflurane – It's no longer used as a general anesthetic due to nephrotoxicity and high blood-gas solubility, leading to prolonged emergence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a morbidly obese patient, desflurane (Option C) is the preferred inhalational anesthetic agent due to its low blood-gas solubility, which facilitates precise control of anesthetic depth and allows for rapid emergence from anesthesia.

 

 

Ref:- Miller’s anesthesia 9th edition pg 610

Propofol is commonly used in anesthesia due to its rapid onset of action, short duration, and antiemetic properties. Understanding its characteristics and benefits is important for anesthesia providers and healthcare practitioners.

questions.text: In which of these situations is nasotracheal intubation contraindicated?

questions.text: A patient is undergoing neurosurgery under general anaesthesia. Before extubation the anaesthetist wants to check recovery from neuromuscular blockade. Which of these nerves is most commonly monitored for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ulnar nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The Ulnar nerve is most commonly monitored for assessing recovery from neuromuscular blockade for several reasons:

 

  • Consistency in Responses: The adductor pollicis muscle, innervated by the ulnar nerve, is more sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents than other muscles. This makes it a good choice for monitoring neuromuscular blockade and ensuring complete reversalbefore extubation.
  • Ease of Monitoring: The ulnar nerve is easily accessible at the wrist, and the thumb's movement (adduction) against resistance can be readily observed and felt. The setup for monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator is straightforward.
  • Minimal Interference: Monitoring at the ulnar nerve has minimal interference from surrounding muscles and structures. This provides a clear assessment of the blockade's depth and recovery.
  • Reliable Predictive Value: The degree of neuromuscular blockade at the adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) is more indicative of blockade in the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for effective breathing and airway protection post-extubation.
  • While other nerves can also be used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, the ulnar nerve's advantages make it the preferred choice in many clinical scenarios, especially for ensuring safe extubation in neurosurgery patients.

 

 

Other nerves that can be monitored:

 

  • Facial nerve  Look for twitch of orbicularis oculi (eye)
  • Posterior tibial nerve  look for twitch of flexor hallucis brevis muscle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve is the most commonly monitored nerve to assess recovery from neuromuscular blockade

 

Ref:- Millers anesthesia 8th edition pg 1610

choices.text: ASA-PS I
ASA-PS II
ASA-PS III
ASA-PS IV

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes is posted for surgery. His HbA1c is 6 gm %. What is his ASA-physical status classification is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ASA-PS II

 

 

In the case presented, the patient is a 45-year-old male with Type II Diabetes, and his HbA1c level is 6%. A HbA1c level of 6% suggests that his diabetes is reasonably well-controlled, and it does not indicate severe systemic disease. Therefore, the appropriate ASA-PS classification for this patient would be:

 

Option B. ASA-PS II (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status II):-This category includes patients with mild to moderate systemic diseases. These conditions are well-controlled and do not limit the patient's daily activities. For example, controlled hypertension, well-managed diabetes, or mild asthma would fall into this category.

In case of Emergency surgery, a suffix `E` is added. For eg: Acute cholecystitis Grade 1`E.

 

Explanation :-

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status classification:

Option A. ASA-PS I (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status I): This category represents a normal healthy patient with no underlying medical conditions. Patients in ASA-PS I have an excellent chance of a successful outcome after surgery.

 

Option C. ASA-PS III (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status III): Patients in this category have severe systemic diseases that limit their daily activities. These conditions may not be well-controlled and could pose significant risks during surgery. Examples include patients with poorly controlled diabetes, significant heart disease, or severe lung disease.

 

Option D. ASA-PS IV (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status IV): This category is reserved for patients with severe systemic diseases that are a constant threat to their life. Patients in this category are often unstable and may require immediate medical attention. Examples include patients with decompensated heart failure, severe respiratory failure, or end-stage organ failure.

 

ASA-PS V (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status V): This category represents patients who are in a moribund state and are not expected to survive without the surgery. The surgery may be performed as a last resort to prolong life, even though the chances of survival are extremely low. Patients in ASA-PS V often have severe, life-threatening conditions and may be comatose or near death.

 

ASA-PS VI (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status VI): This category includes patients who have been declared brain-dead but are being kept on life support for the purpose of organ donation. These patients are not expected to recover, and their organs are being preserved for transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:-

American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System

 

Advantages of ASA-PS grading: Helps to decide mortality and Morbidity,

Disadvantages: Does not explain the airway assessment, does not tell the anesthesia pain

 

Reference:- Millers 8th edition page number 1144

questions.text: Which of these Mapleson circuit is the best for spontaneous ventilation in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  A>D>C>B

 

(Mnemonic - All Dogs Can Bite)

 

  • To prevent rebreathing a fresh gas flow equal to minute ventilation is important.
  • In all Mapleson circuits, rebreathing of carbon dioxide is prevented by an adequate fresh gas flow and by the presence of adjustable pressure release valve. The exhaled carbon dioxide flows through the outer corrugated tube and out via this valve from where it can be scavenged.
  • The Mapleson A circuit is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation because it requires a fresh gas inflow rate of only 1 times minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide.
  • Thus, the Mapleson A design is the most efficient for spontaneous ventilation.
  • Mapleson A is also called Magill’s circuit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For spontaneous ventilation in adults, the Mapleson A circuit (Magill’s circuit) is the most efficient, followed by D, C, and B, in decreasing order of efficiency. This is because Mapleson A requires the lowest fresh gas flow rate to prevent carbon dioxide rebreathing. The mnemonic "All Dogs Can Bite" can be used to remember the order A>D>C>B for their efficiency in preventing rebreathing during spontaneous ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anesthesia equipment 210-219

choices.text: Induction Dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% Thiopentone.
It Reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective
It is Ultra-Short Acting due to Rapid Metabolism & Excretion.
Intra-Arterial Injection cause Pain & Vasospasm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Thiopentone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is Ultra-Short Acting due to Rapid Metabolism & Excretion.

 

Option C. This statement is not true. Thiopentone is ultra-short acting primarily due to rapid redistribution of the drug from the brain to other tissues in the body, rather than rapid metabolism and excretion. This redistribution leads to the rapid termination of its anesthetic effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Induction Dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% Thiopentone: This statement is true. The typical induction dose of Thiopentone is 3-5 mg/kg of a 2.5% solution. The dose may vary depending on the patient's age, weight, and specific clinical circumstances.

 

Option B. It Reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective: This statement is true. Thiopentone is considered cerebroprotective because it Reduces Intra-Cranial Pressure (ICP) by depressing cerebral metabolism. It can be used in patients with raised ICP and seizures to help manage intracranial hypertension.

 

Option D. Intra Intra-Arterial Injection cause Pain & Vasospasm: This statement is true. Intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone is associated with pain at the injection site and vasospasm, which can lead to adverse effects, including potential ischemia in the affected limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone is an ultra-short-acting intravenous induction agent primarily due to rapid redistribution, not rapid metabolism and excretion.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 7th edition page 318-324

questions.text: Maximum etCO2 is measured at the end of which phase of the capnograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phase III

 

Explanation:

 

 

Phases of Capnograph:

 

  • Phase I (Inspiratory Baseline) reflects inspired air, which is normally devoid of CO2.
  • Phase II (Expiratory Upstroke) reflects the dead space air (trachea and conduction bronchi)
  • Phase III is the Alveolar Plateau.
  • Phase IV/Phase 0 is the Inspiratory Downstroke, the beginning of the next inspiration.
  • Maximum measured etCO2 is seen at the end of phase III

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum end-tidal carbon dioxide (etCO2) measurement is observed at the end of Phase III in the capnograph waveform, which represents the alveolar plateau.

 

Ref:- Dorsch and Dorsch anesthesia equipment, 5th ed, pg. 1023-1024

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with cancer of the Hard palate completely blocking the oral cavity is in severe respiratory distress. His SpO2 on room air is 90%. The ENT surgeon decides to do an emergency tracheostomy to relieve the airway obstruction. What is the ASA-PS classification of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. ASA-PS VE

 

Explanation:-

Option C. ASA-PS VE (American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status VE): This designation is used for patients who are facing a situation of extreme emergency or urgency.

ASA-PS classification is used to quantify the peri-operative risk before surgery.

 

In this case, the patient's airway is completely blocked due to cancer of the hard palate, and he is in severe respiratory distress. The decision to perform an emergency tracheostomy is made to relieve the airway obstruction and ensure the patient's oxygenation. This situation is considered extremely urgent, and that's why it is classified as ASA-PS VE.

 

Educational Objective:-

ASA-PS VE classification is assigned to a patient with a very severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, such as in the case of severe respiratory distress due to an airway obstruction in a cancer patient.

choices.text: S and C technique
C and E technique
D and E technique

questions.text: What is the name of this technique of mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C and E technique

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a technique commonly used in medical settings during bag and mask ventilation.

 

The technique illustrated is known as the "C and E Technique," which is a method employed during Bag-Valve-Mask (BVM) ventilation. This approach is utilized to maintain an open airway and ensure effective ventilation in patients who are not breathing adequately or at all.

 

The "C and E" refers to the hand placement:

 

  • "C" represents the shape formed by the thumb and index finger, which are placed on the mask to create an airtight seal against the patient's face.
  • "E" signifies the remaining fingers (middle, ring, and little fingers) that are positioned under the mandible (jawbone) to lift and thrust the jaw forward. This maneuver helps in keeping the airway open by preventing the tongue from occluding the oropharynx.
  • The thumb and index fingers pressing against the mask while the other fingers lift the jaw forms the distinctive "C" and "E" shapes, hence the name. The jaw thrust achieved by the "E" fingers is vital as it elevates the tongue off the back wall of the throat, reducing airway obstruction and facilitating better airflow during artificial ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The technique depicted in the image is known as the 'C and E technique' for mask ventilation during bag-valve-mask (BVM) ventilation. This technique involves forming a 'C' shape with the thumb and index finger to create an airtight mask seal and using the remaining fingers to lift and thrust the jaw forward ('E' shape) to maintain an open airway, preventing tongue obstruction during artificial ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 446

It is defined as the concentration that prevents movement in response to skin incision in 50% of unpremedicated subjects studied at sea level (1 atmosphere), in 100% oxygen.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is posted for Modified radical mastectomy under general anesthesia. Halfway through the surgery, this is her capnograph. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat Muscle Relaxant

 

This capnograph shows a ‘Curare Cleft’

 

Option B: The ‘Curare Cleft’ is an indication that the patient is out of neuromuscular blockade and is making an attempt to breathe spontaneously. As they are halfway through the surgery, a top up dose of muscle relaxant needs to be given to paralyze the patient again.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Patient cannot be extubated as they are halfway through the surgery.
 

Option C: Deepening anaesthesia will not paralyze the patient.
 

Option D: Patient cannot be reversed from neuromuscular blockade as they are halfway through the surgery, surgery is not over.

 

Educational Objective:

In cases where the capnograph waveform shows a curare cleft in the capnograph during surgery, the appropriate next step may be to repeat the muscle relaxant to ensure adequate muscle paralysis for the procedure.

Uses of EtCO2:

A) It is the surest sign of Intubation

B) To diagnose a venous air embolism

C) To diagnose any circuit disconnections

D) To identify Bronchospasm intra-operatively

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is posted for posterior fossa tumour excision surgery under general anesthesia. Which of these inhalational agents having the lowest blood gas partition coefficient can be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

Option C. Desflurane has the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient among the options of approximately 0.45, which means it has a rapid onset and emergence from anesthesia. This makes desflurane particularly useful for surgeries where quick recovery of consciousness is desired.

 

Explanation:

 

For a 65-year-old man undergoing posterior fossa tumor excision surgery, an inhalational agent with a low blood-gas partition coefficient is desirable for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia due to the need for neurosurgical procedures to have precise control over anesthetic depth and cerebral relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When selecting an inhalational anesthetic for neurosurgery, it is important to consider the blood-gas partition coefficient. A lower coefficient allows for rapid changes in anesthetic depth, which is beneficial for neurosurgical patients. Desflurane, with the lowest blood-gas partition coefficient among the options listed, is suitable for such cases due to its rapid induction and recovery profile.

 

 

Ref:- Millers anesthesia 9th edition pg 610

choices.text: Curare notch is seen during rebreathing.
It is gold standard for confirmation of endotracheal intubation.
In malignant hyperthermia there is a rise in etCO2

questions.text: Which one of these statements is not true regarding capnography?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Curare Notch is seen during rebreathing.

 

Option B. Statement is False . The Curare Notch, also known as the "Curare Cleft" or "Phase II Dip," refers to a transient drop in the plateau phase (phase III) of the capnogram. It's named after the neuromuscular blocking agent curare, which was used historically. The Curare notch can be seen when a paralyzed patient attempts to take a spontaneous breath during mechanical ventilation. It has nothing to do with rebreathing. Rebreathing would be more likely to cause an overall increase in baseline etCO2.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. etCO2 decreases in pulmonary embolism: True. End-tidal carbon dioxide (etCO2) represents the partial pressure of CO2 at the end of an exhaled breath and is an indirect marker of the CO2 levels in arterial blood. In Pulmonary Embolism (PE), there is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs. This blockage can result in decreased blood flow to the lungs and can reduce CO2 elimination, leading to a decrease in etCO2 levels. Capnography can show a sudden drop in etCO2 in cases of PE.

 

Option C. It is Gold standard for confirmation of Endotracheal Intubation: True. Capnography is considered the gold standard for confirming the correct placement of an endotracheal tube in the trachea.

 

Option D. In malignant hyperthermia there is a rise in etCO2: True. Malignant hyperthermia is a rare life-threatening condition triggered by certain drugs used during general anesthesia. Affected individuals have a hypermetabolic reaction, leading to an increased production of CO2. This increased production can be detected early as a rise in etCO2 on capnography, even before a significant rise in body temperature, making capnography a valuable tool in early detection and management of malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capnography, the measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide (etCO2), serves as a valuable tool in various clinical scenarios. It is indeed the gold standard for confirming the correct placement of an endotracheal tube in the trachea, and it detects early changes in CO2 levels in conditions such as malignant hyperthermia, leading to a rise in etCO2. However, it is important to note that the 'Curare notch' in the capnogram is not associated with rebreathing; instead, it is seen when a paralyzed patient attempts to take a spontaneous breath during mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref:- Millers anesthesia 9th edition pg 1313-1315

questions.text: Identify the monitor in the picture below which is commonly used intra-operatively during mitral valve repair surgeries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Transesophageal Echo

 

 

Option B. Trans Esophageal Echo (TEE): This is the monitor depicted in the image. For this procedure, a probe is inserted through the mouth and into the esophagus, positioning it directly behind the heart. This allows for very detailed images of the heart's structures and is particularly useful for evaluating the heart's valves, especially the mitral valve. TEE is especially beneficial intra-operatively during heart surgeries like mitral valve repairs because it provides real-time feedback to surgeons about the valve's function, enabling adjustments as needed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trans Thoracic echo (TTE): This is a type of echocardiogram that uses a transducer placed on the chest wall to obtain images of the heart. It is non-invasive and provides pictures of the heart's chambers, valves, and surrounding structures. TTE is commonly used to assess overall heart function and can be used to detect heart conditions. It's typically the first type of echocardiogram ordered when heart issues are suspected.

 

Option C. Pulmonary Artery Catheter: Also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter, this device is inserted into a large vein and then guided through the right side of the heart and into the pulmonary artery. Its primary purpose is to measure pressures in the heart, helping to diagnose and manage various heart and lung conditions. While it provides valuable hemodynamic data, it doesn't offer the direct visual information about cardiac structures like an echo does.

 

Option D. 2D Echo: The term "2D Echo" simply refers to the two-dimensional images produced by these echocardiograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transesophageal Echo is used for diagnosing:

 

  1. Structural diseases of heart
  2. Hemodynamic instability
  3. Systolic and diastolic heat failure
  4. Pericardial tamponade
  5. Cardiac output
  6. Cause of hypotension intra-operatively
  7. Venous air embolism

 

 

Ref:- Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesia 5th ed pg 114

Ans. B) 4 hours prior to surgery

 

Explanation:-

In infants scheduled for congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair, it's generally recommended to continue breastmilk feeding up to 4 hours before the surgery. This allows the baby to receive nutrition and hydration while minimizing the risk of aspiration during anesthesia induction.

choices.text: Face Mask with Reservoir

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with COVID pneumonia is admitted to the casualty with respiratory distress and spo2 85% on room air. Maximum oxygen concentration can be delivered by which oxygen delivery device?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Face Mask with Reservoir

 

Option D. Reservoir Face Mask:

 

  • It is a variable performance device. These masks provide a higher FiO2 as there is a reservoir bag attached to the face mask. Oxygen flows directly into the reservoir bag. The patient inhales oxygen preferentially from the reservoir. FiO2 varies depending on mask fit, capacity of reservoir bag, Oxygen flow rates and patient’s inspiratory flow.

 

Partial rebreathing mask is a simple mask with a reservoir bag. At a flow of 6–10 L/min the system can provide 40–70% oxygen. Non-rebreathing masks are similar to partial rebreathing masks but do not permit the mixing of exhaled gases with the fresh gas supply. There should be a minimum flow of 10 L/min. The delivered FiO2 of this system is 75–90% at flow rates of 12–15 L/m.

 

Explanation:

 

Oxygen Therapy Devices

 

  • Supplemental Oxygen can be supplied by a variety of devices.

 

Option A. Venturi Mask:

 

  • It is the high flow, fixed performance device. An air-entrainment mask contains a jet orifice and air entrainment ports and is designed to fit over the patient’s nose and mouth. The oxygen is supplied to the mask through narrow bore oxygen tubing under pressure. When oxygen under pressure is forced through a small jet orifice entering the mask, a negative pressure is created, which caused room air to be entrained into the mask through the apertures in the Venturi barrel. The resultant air-oxygen mixture containing the prescribed O2 concentration flows into the face piece for patient breathing. Due to the high-flow rates, the excess gas flushes out the expired CO2 through the holes on the sides of the mask. As a result, of this there is no rebreathing or no increase in dead space. When oxygen flow is increased, more air is entrained, to maintain a constant oxygen concentration. The system is called HAFOE (High Air Flow with Oxygen Enrichment). Variations in the size of the entrainment ports determine the FiO2 and variation in the oxygen flow rate determines the total flow delivered. The entrainment mechanism is based on the principles described by Bernoulli. The FiO2 can be precisely controlled from 0.24-0.6. (24–60%) at high-flow rates by simply exchanging the interchangeable jet nozzles and adjusting the oxygen flow rate.
     

Flow rate and FiO2 with Venturi Mask

 

 

Option B. Nasal Cannula:
 

  • Are low flow variable performance devices with no capacity. They consist of two soft prongs that arise from oxygen supply tubing. The prongs are inserted into the patient’s anterior nares, and the tubing is secured to the patient’s face by an adjustable strap. Oxygen is delivered through the cannula, but at low flow rates between 0.5–5.0 L/min. The patient’s nasopharynx acts as an anatomic reservoir. When the patient inspires, the oxygen is diluted with room air. The degree of dilution depends on the patient’s inspiratory flows. The resulting FiO2 depends on the flow rate of oxygen, patient’s minute ventilation and inspiratory flow and the volume of the nasopharynx. The FiO2 cannot therefore be precisely controlled, but the maximal tracheal FiO2 is not likely to exceed 0.4 (40%).
  • So, the disadvantage of using nasal cannula is it delivers an unpredictable FiO2 with a maximum estimated FiO2 of 0.4.

 

Option C. Face Mask:
 

  • Simple face mask is a low flow variable performance device with small capacity. They are plastic reservoirs designed to fit the patients’ nose and mouth. An elastic strap is used to secure the mask around the patient’s head.
  • Simple oxygen mask can provide 35–60% FiO2, at flow rates 5–10 L/Min. Like nasal cannula face mask also delivers an unpredictable FiO2 with not more than FiO2 of 0.6.

 

Educational Objective:-

 

 

 

Ref: Understanding Anesthetic Equipment and Procedures, Dwarkadas K Baheti Pg 233-238

choices.text: Cervical Spine Injury
Head and Neck Surgery

questions.text: Identify the condition in which this manoeuvre is used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cervical Spine Injury

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. MILS is used during airway management in patients with suspected or known cervical spine injuries to prevent additional spinal cord damage.

 

Explanation:

 

The maneuver described is Manual In-Line Stabilization (MILS), which is specifically used in the context of a suspected cervical spine injury.

 

The primary goal of MILS is to maintain the cervical spine in a neutral alignment during airway manipulation, which could otherwise cause secondary injury to the spinal cord. After the airway is secured, MILS is replaced with more definitive immobilization devices like a cervical collar, lateral blocks, sandbags, and head and chin straps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MANUAL IN-LINE STABILISATION (MILS)

 

MILS is performed by an assistant during airway management to maintain a neutral position and prevent inadvertent movement of the head and neck to provide airway management with cervical spine stabilization, by either:

 

  • Crouching beside the intubator with hands placed on the patient’s mastoid processes or cradling the occiput
  • Standing beside the patient in front of the intubator with hands placed on the sides of the patient’s head and forearms resting on the patient’s chest
  • Traction must not be applied
  • Note that there is no universal definition of neutral position

 

MILS is replaced by a cervical collar, lateral blocks/sandbags, and head and chin straps once the airway is secure.

 

 

Ref: https://litfl.com/airway-and-cervical-spine-injury/

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who is a known hypertensive is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy under general anesthesia. Post the surgery his serum creatinine goes up to 4.5 and he has kidney failure. What could be the causative inhalational agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Methoxyflurane

 

Methoxyflurane is the most Nephrotoxic Inhalational Agent as it produces a large number of Inorganic Fluorides causing Polyuric Renal Failure.

Least Nephrotoxic is Desflurane.

 

Explanation:

Option-A) Desflurane is minimally metabolized, so it is used in renal surgeries

Option B) Isoflurane is also considered to have a lower risk of nephrotoxicity compared to methoxyflurane and is used in clinical practice.

Option-D) Sevoflurane contains a good amount of Fluoride ions. In the lower group of animals, it reacts with soda lime to form compound A which is nephrotoxic. But in humans, no effect is seen.
 

 

Educational objective:

All inhalational Anaesthetic agents decrease Renal blood flow. Methoxyflurane causes maximum renal injury in form of acute tubular necrosis because of the presence of Maximum Fluoride ions

 

 

Ref:- Miller’s anesthesia 9th edition pg 530

questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apfel Score

 

Explanation:-

 

Apfel score is used for scoring Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) score.

 

 

Educational Objective:

The Apfel score is not a test employed for airway assessment in clinical practice.
