questions.text: A 50-year-old man has undergone a day care laparoscopic hernia repair. What scoring system is typically used to assess when a patient is ready for discharge from the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) following day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aldrete score

 

 

Option D. The Aldrete scoring system is commonly used to assess when a patient has recovered from the physiological effects of anesthesia. It considers five parameters: consciousness, respiration, circulation, oxygen saturation, and color, mobility and sensation of extremities. A score of 9 or 10 (out of a maximum of 10) is usually required for a patient to be considered ready for discharge from the PACU.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. APGAR score - This is a quick scoring system used to assess the physical status of a newborn immediately after birth. It's not relevant for assessing recovery from anesthesia in adults.

 

Option B. ASA physical status classification - This is used to assess a patient's overall health status prior to anesthesia, but it's not used for assessing recovery from anesthesia.

 

Option C. Mallampati score - This is used to predict the ease of intubation, but it's not used for assessing recovery from anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Aldrete score is a common scoring system employed to assess a patient's readiness for discharge from the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU) after day care surgery, considering parameters such as consciousness, oxygen saturation, hemodynamic stability, respiratory status, and ability to move.

Reference : Morgan and Mikhails clinical anesthesiology 7th edition pg 2417

choices.text: It is used in Children.
It can be used for Spontaneous as well as Controlled Ventilation.
It is used for patients weighing less than 20 kg.
All of the above statements are correct.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the circuit given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above statements are correct.

 

Option D. Since all the previous statements are correct, this statement is also correct.

 

Explanation:

 

Mapleson F or Jackson Rees’ circuit is the circuit of choice for paediatrics in both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

 

It is used in neonates, infants, and paediatric patients less than 20 kg in weight or less than 5 years of age.

 

Option A. It is used in children: This is correct. The Mapleson F circuit is indeed commonly used in pediatric anesthesia due to its simplicity and effectiveness for smaller patients.

 

Option B. It can be used for spontaneous as well as controlled ventilation: This is also correct. The Mapleson F circuit can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation, with the clinician either allowing the child to breathe on their own or manually ventilating with the attached bag.

 

Option C. It is used for patients weighing less than 20 kg: This statement is correct as well. The Mapleson F circuit is suitable for neonates, infants, and pediatric patients typically less than 20 kg or those less than 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mapleson F or Jackson Rees’ circuit is designed for pediatric patients, suitable for those weighing less than 20 kg, and can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation. Understanding the specific requirements of fresh gas flow and the functioning of this circuit is essential for safe pediatric anesthesia practice.

 

  • The flows required to prevent rebreathing are 2.5-3.0 times the minute volume during spontaneous ventilation and 1.5 to 2 times a minute volume during controlled ventilation.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition page 612

questions.text: Dr. Soonawalla is preparing to perform a diagnostic procedure on a 70-year-old patient with cardiovascular comorbidities. The procedure involves potential discomfort but is relatively brief and does not require significant surgical intervention. The patient has expressed a wish to be sedated but not completely unconscious, and to have no recall of the procedure. Which type of anesthesia care would be the most suitable in this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC)

 

Option D. Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC) - Correct. MAC involves the administration of sedatives, analgesics, and/or local or regional anesthesia to provide comfort and pain control. The level of sedation can be adjusted from mild (patient is awake but relaxed) to deep (patient is on the edge of consciousness but can be aroused). Importantly, one of the goals of MAC is to ensure that the patient has no recall of the procedure, which aligns with this patient's preferences. Furthermore, MAC is often suitable for patients with comorbidities, as it can offer a safer profile than general anesthesia for certain patients.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Local Anesthesia - This type of anesthesia is often used for minor procedures and numbs a small area of the body.

 

Option B. General Anesthesia - Under general anesthesia, the patient is completely unconscious. This might be more than what is necessary for this patient's relatively brief, non-major procedure. Plus, given the patient's cardiovascular comorbidities, the risks of general anesthesia could be unnecessarily high.

 

Option C. Regional Anesthesia - This type of anesthesia numbs a larger area of the body than local anesthesia but doesn't make the patient unconscious

 

Educational objective

For brief diagnostic procedures requiring sedation without complete unconsciousness, especially in patients with cardiovascular comorbidities, Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC) is the most suitable anesthesia care type to ensure comfort, manage pain, and prevent procedure recall while minimizing risk.

 

Types of Anaesthesia - 

 

Reference: Morgan & Mikhails Clinical Anesthesiology seventh edition page 29-30.

questions.text: Which of these intravenous induction agents is preferred in cardiac surgeries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Etomidate

 

Explanation:

 

In cardiac surgeries, Etomidate is often the preferred intravenous induction agent. This is because Etomidate is the most Cardio-Stable (Hemodynamically Stable) among the intravenous induction agents. It causes the least hemodynamic disturbance, making it suitable for patients with cardiac disease, such as heart failure, valve dysfunction, or those undergoing aneurysm, bypass, or valve surgery.

 

Other intravenous induction agents like Propofol, Thiopental, and Barbiturates can cause dose-dependent vasodilation and hypotension, which may not be well-tolerated in patients with compromised cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etomidate is the preferred intravenous induction agent in cardiac surgeries due to its minimal impact on hemodynamic, making it a safe choice for patients with cardiac conditions undergoing surgical procedures.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 335

choices.text: Atropine
Midazolam
Fentanyl
Aspirin

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically used as a premedication drug before anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin

 

Option D. Aspirin is not typically used as a premedication before anesthesia. In fact, patients are usually advised to stop taking aspirin in the days leading up to surgery, as it can increase the risk of bleeding. Aspirin is an anti-platelet drug and does not have the sedative, analgesic, or anti-anxiety properties typically desired in premedication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atropine - Atropine is often used as a premedication before anesthesia as an antisialagogue.

 

Option B. Midazolam - Midazolam is a benzodiazepine commonly used for its sedative and anxiety-relieving effects before surgery.

 

Option C. Fentanyl - Fentanyl is an opioid that may be used as a premedication before anesthesia for its strong pain-relieving properties.

 

Educational Objective:-

 

 

Ref: Sharp D. Premedication. In: Freeman BS, Berger JS. eds. Anesthesiology Core Review: Part One Basic Exam. McGraw-Hill Education; 2014. Accessed February 03, 2024.  https://accessanesthesiology.mhmedical.com/content.aspx?

choices.text: To know the potency of General Anesthesia
To know the speed of Induction
To monitor the depth of General Anesthesia
To monitor the depth of Neuromuscular Blockade

questions.text: The monitor shown below is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To monitor the depth of General Anesthesia

 

This is the primary purpose of the BIS monitor. The BIS monitor calculates a number (BIS value) between 0 (no brain activity) and 100 (fully awake). A lower BIS value indicates a deeper level of anesthesia. Typically, a BIS value between 40 and 60 suggests an appropriate depth for general anesthesia where the patient is unconscious and unlikely to remember the surgery, making it a valuable tool in preventing awareness during surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

The monitor shown above is a Bipsectral Index monitor.

 

Bispectral Index

 

  • It is the first scientifically validated and commercially available monitor to check depth of anaesthesia.
  • It utilizes many parameters like EEG signals, eye blinks etc. to calculate a score. The score varies between 0-100.
  • A score of 45-60 is considered as adequate depth (score of 100 is for fully awake state and 0 is for completely silent brain).
     

 

Let’s explain each option:

 

Option A. To know the potency of General Anesthesia: Potency usually refers to the concentration or dose of an anesthetic agent required to produce a specific effect. While the BIS monitor can give insights into how the brain is responding to anesthesia, it doesn't directly measure the potency of the agent being used.

 

Option B. To know the speed of Induction: The speed of induction refers to how quickly a patient becomes anesthetized after the administration of an anesthetic agent. While the BIS value can decrease as a patient becomes more anesthetized, the primary purpose of BIS monitoring isn't to measure this speed.

 

Option D. To monitor the depth of Neuromuscular Blockade: Neuromuscular blockade is achieved using specific drugs to paralyze muscles during surgery. The depth of neuromuscular blockade is usually monitored using peripheral nerve stimulators and not with a BIS monitor

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bispectral Index Monitor, commonly referred to as the BIS monitor, is a valuable tool in anesthesia and critical care. It measures and quantifies a patient's level of consciousness and depth of anesthesia by analyzing EEG (electroencephalogram) patterns. The BIS monitor provides real-time feedback to anesthesiologists, helping them maintain an appropriate balance of anesthesia during surgical procedures and improve patient outcomes.

 

 

Ref:- Understanding anaesthetic equipment and procedures – Baheti, first ed pg 304

choices.text: Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is Low.
Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is Normal.
Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is High.
Flow of CO2 during inhalation, which is Normal.

questions.text: An intern posted in OT was asked to identify the parameter marked with the arrow in the patient monitor and interpret the value. Which of the following options is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is normal.

 

Option B. This suggests that the carbon dioxide being exhaled by the patient is within the expected and typical range. The monitor shows a value of 39, which generally indicates the end-tidal carbon dioxide (etCO2) level. This is the correct answer.

 

An etCO2 value between 35-45 mmHg is considered normal for most adults, so the value of 39 falls within this range. This is the correct interpretation.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is low: This would imply that the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) being exhaled by the patient is below the expected range. This could be due to various reasons including hypoventilation, decreased metabolic rate, or certain pharmacological agents that decrease CO2 production. However, based on the monitor, the value is within a normal range, so this option is not correct.

 

Option C. Flow of CO2 during exhalation, which is high: This would mean that the amount of carbon dioxide being exhaled by the patient is higher than the typical range. Elevated etCO2 levels can be due to conditions like hyperthermia, sepsis, or rebreathing of expired CO2 among others. However, as stated earlier, the value of 39 is within the normal range, so this option is not accurate.

 

Option D. Flow of CO2 during inhalation, which is normal: This implies that we're measuring the carbon dioxide levels when the patient is inhaling, which isn't the case with the monitor shown. EtCO2 monitoring reflects the CO2 levels during exhalation. Moreover, we don't typically measure CO2 during inhalation as it's expected to be minimal in the inhaled air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal capnogram is shown below:

 

 

Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 at the end of each exhaled breath (end-tidal CO2 or etCO2)

 

Ref:- Understanding anaesthetic equipment and procedures, Baheti, first ed Pg 288

choices.text: For Intubation in an Anticipated Difficult Airway
Guide Placement of Double Lumen Tube
Suction of Blood from the Airways

questions.text: Identify the use of the equipment shown below in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the Above

 

Option D. Since the bronchoscope can be used for all the above-mentioned purposes, this option is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. For Intubation in an Anticipated Difficult Airway: A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope is often used to navigate and visualize the airway in cases where difficult intubation is anticipated, such as with abnormal airway anatomy.

 

Option B. Guide Placement of Double Lumen Tube: In thoracic surgery requiring lung isolation, a double-lumen endotracheal tube is used, and a fiberoptic bronchoscope is often employed to confirm proper placement and position of the tube.

 

Option C. Suction of Blood from the Airways: While primarily used for visualization, a bronchoscope can also assist in the suctioning of blood or secretions from the airway when necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A flexible fiberoptic bronchoscope and understand its multifunctional use in airway management, including aiding difficult intubations, guiding the placement of double-lumen tubes, and clearing the airways of obstructions such as blood or secretions.

 

 

Ref: Understanding anaesthetic equipment and procedures 5th edition page 242

questions.text: Identify the part marked in the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Murphys eye

 

The part of the endotracheal tube indicated by the arrows in the image is known as Murphy's eye.

 

This is a hole on the side of the distal end of the tube. It is designed to provide an alternative pathway for airflow in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, thus ensuring continuous ventilation.

 

Murphys Eye. This feature is a safety mechanism to reduce the risk of complete airway obstruction if the end of the tube becomes occluded by mucus, blood, or the tracheal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cuff: The cuff is a balloon-like structure near the end of the tube, which is inflated to secure the tube within the trachea and prevent air from leaking around the tube.

 

Option B. Radiological Mark: This is typically a line or series of markings along the length of the tube that can be seen on an X-ray to help determine the position of the tube within the trachea.

 

Option D. Distal End: The distal end is the tip of the endotracheal tube that enters the trachea, but it is not what is being indicated by the arrows in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Murphy's eye on an endotracheal tube as a secondary opening that provides an alternative path for ventilation, which is crucial if the main lumen becomes blocked.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhails Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page no. 321
